newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish 3-day rev repo cut seen not affecting rates.
newsitem.headline: Polish 3-day rev repo cut seen not affecting rates.

text.p: The National Bank of Poland's (NBP) reverse repo rate cut earlier today was a result of the money market's overliquidity and should not affect deposit rates or T-bill yields next week, analysts said.
The NBP cut its three-day reverse repo maximum rate to 17.70 percent from 19.12 percent at the last drainage, a 14-day operation on Tuesday.
"The cut was not caused by the NBP's will to lower drainage rates, but was rather the result of the market's huge cash surplus," said Marek Wieczorkiewicz, chief dealer at PKO BP.
"Drainage rates may still rebound," Wieczorkiewicz added.
Analysts said Friday's move to mop up liquidity would not likely be used as a benchmark because it was much shorter than the NBP's main reverse repo 14-day period.
"Today's reverse repo should not be considered a full fledged drainage, it is more like a spot/next deposit," said one foreign bank dealer in Warsaw.

On the money market overnight rates closed at 6.0/8.0 percent, down from 12.0/13.0 percent at the opening and Thursday's 15.0/17.0. Tomorrow/next rates were at 12.5/17.0 percent against 9.0/12.0 in early trade and 12.0/16.8 on Thursday.
Analysts said longer-term deposit rates on the money market still used the 19.12 percent 14-day reverse repo rate as a benchmark and did not move after today's cut in the reverse repo rate.
